Why Climate Activists Shut Down Journalists‚Äô Joe Manchin Event

By Andrew Perez

The event perfectly encapsulated the problems with Beltway news outlets‚Äô lucrative corporate sponsorship model. By seeking out fossil fuel industry cash and cozying up to the industry‚Äôs favorite politicians as the world burns, media outlets are picking a side in the battle to protect the planet‚Äôs future livability ‚Äî settling down with the arsonists against all other life on Earth.

‚ÄúMedia outlets need to reevaluate,‚Äù said Rylee Haught, an organizer with the environmental group Climate Defiance who was involved in the protest. ‚ÄúIf they‚Äôre taking giant chunks of cash from fossil fuel CEOs, they should be prepared for us to call them out at any time and shut down an event like this. When you‚Äôre platforming people like [Manchin], you need to be prepared.‚Äù
Sponsored by groups with major ties to fossil fuel interests, the

was meant to ‚Äúexplore the futureshape [sic]‚Äù of permitting reform as ‚ÄúAmerica‚Äôs economy enters a period of substantial infrastructure investment.‚Äù The outlet‚Äôs Beltway journalists were scheduled to interview ‚Äúpolicy makers, business leaders, advocacy groups, and thought leaders‚Äù ‚Äî including Manchin.

The conservative Democrat helped write many of the permitting reform provisions included in the recent debt ceiling law negotiated by President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.). Broadly speaking, the changes will expedite energy and pipeline projects.

Manchin publicly championed provisions in the legislation to fast-track the Mountain Valley Pipeline from West Virginia to southern Virginia, and shield the long-stalled project from further environmental challenges. Environmental groups
the pipeline would emit at least 26 coal plants‚Äô worth of greenhouse gasses and exacerbate the climate crisis.
‚ÄúCongrats on that Mountain Valley Pipeline, how‚Äôd you do that?‚Äù
‚Äôs editor-at-large, Steve Clemons, said to Manchin at the start of their conversation.
Within two minutes, activists with Climate Defiance had interrupted the interview, shouting about Manchin‚Äôs ‚Äúdirty deal.‚Äù

All in all, the event lived up to its promise to illustrate the ‚Äúfutureshape‚Äù of something ‚Äî not permitting reform, but rather the looming clash between industry-funded news media and activists who want to save the planet.

One of the more odious developments in this corporate-sponsored news model is the events companies are hosting with writers and newsmakers, in the name of dialogue. Climate Defiance‚Äôs decision to protest at events with journalists and policymakers is deliberate: Politicians and media are both climate problems for the same reason.

‚ÄúNot only does Biden need to be held accountable, but we know that the same folks that are funding the worst politicians are also passing out cash to the corporate media outlets that will continue to say the things that the fossil fuels CEOs want them to say, more than uplifting folks like us,‚Äù said Haught.
